It was originally Ken's rtNEAT code I took, I added some code from 
Tyler S=
treeter's leakyNEAT for the leaky integrator activation code, 
and implemen=
ted my own HyperNEAT/CPPN code on top of all this. It 
turned into.. someth=
ing like "UltimateNEAT" :)
I am currently keeping this in my own CVS reposi=
tory, but I will 
publish it here along with the code for the humanoid.  
I=
 got the humanoid from Tyler Streeter's AVH code. I modified it a 
bit, and=
 it does not use hard-coded OpenGL anymore, but the Irrlicht 
open source 3=
D engine. 
The program is a bit shitty, the user interface sucks, but it's =
an 
experiment at all... 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Gauci" <jgma=
th2000@...> wrote:
>
> This is really interesting stuff!
> 
> Did you use m=
y HyperNEAT implementation or are you rolling your 
own?  
> If you used mi=
ne, did you have any trouble getting it to work?  If 
> you used your own, =
are you going to publish some source code?
> 
> P.S. Where do you get 3d hu=
manoid physics models from?
> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_=
chervenski" 
> <petar_chervenski@> wrote:
> >
> > Hello there, 
> > 
> > I =
am using the following CPPN model for the substrate: 
> > 
> > Inputs: X1, =
Y1, X2, Y2, BIAS
> > Outputs: Weight, Node-Bias, Node-Time_Constant
> > 
> =
> The time constant range is [0.5 .. 5.0] and the weight/node-bias 
> range=
 
> > within the substrate in [-8.0 .. 8.0]. 
> > The weight range in the C=
PPN is unbounded. 
> > 
> > The node-specific outputs are computed using (X=
1, Y1, BIAS) and 
the 
> > others set to 0.
> > 
> > The activation functio=
ns used are plain sigmoid, gaussian, and 
> sine. 
> > The CTRNN substrate =
activates with 0.02 timestep and it is used 
to 
> > control a 3D humanoid =
model, simulated in a physical environment 
> (using 
> > Open Dynamics Eng=
ine http://www.ode.org ). 
> > 
> > The thing I notice, is the following: 
=
> > 
> > The first networks are simple, and so the connective patterns 
are=
. 
> But 
> > the node biases and time constants are also simple. When I wa=
tch 
an 
> > animaion of the activation changing in the substrate, it looks=
 
like 
> it 
> > exibits a pattern. The simplest I've seen can be describe=
d as a 
> mexican 
> > wave travelling across the hidden nodes. 
> > As the=
 CPPNs complexify, so do the activity patterns exibited. 
When 
> > using r=
egular NEAT for the problem of keeping the humanoid model 
> > balanced, it=
 has moslty erratic behaviour, and the lucky ones 
(with 
> > high fitness)=
 usually find a way to trick the system and stay in 
a 
> > balanced positi=
on forever, without moving at all. 
> > But when HyperNEAT is used for this=
, it looks really interesting 
> and.. 
> > natural! The model is trying to=
 balance using its arms, and it is 
> > moving.. It looks like a drunk guy,=
 but you note the difference. 
> > I've arranged the nodes in a geometric w=
ay.. Let me explain - the 
> left 
> > and right arm's outputs are separate=
d in the left and right in 
the 
> > substrate space, and close to each oth=
er. So do the legs. The 
> hidden 
> > nodes are in the center in a star/ci=
rlular shape. I also included 
3 
> > inputs (head velocity) in the center =
around 0.0, but with smaller 
> > radius than the ring of hidden nodes. 
> =
> 
> > Peter
> >
>
